msContents.summary:
An Ethiopian manuscript of the Discourse of John Chrysostom in praise of the Archangels Michael, Gabriel and Raphael written in Geez, the ancient liturgical language of the Ethiopian church.
St. John Chrysostom (347–407) was a Patriarchate (Archbishop) of Constantinople and one of the most important writers of the early Christian Church. His writings are thought to have been translated into Geez from the Greek by Syrian monks who founded monasteries in Ethiopia.
The text was written by a single scribe and begins with a Discourse of John Chrysostom on the Four Beasts (ff. 2v-10v) and a painting of the Trinity (ff. 11r) followed by a Discourse for the festivals of the Archangel Michael by Demetrius, the second-third century Patriarch (Archbishop) of Alexandria (ff. 11v-62v); Miracles of the Archangel Michael (ff. 63r-81r); Discourses for the festivals of the Archangel Gabriel (ff. 82v-83r); Miracles of the Archangel Gabriel (ff. 83v-84r); the Discourse of John Chrysostom in praise of the Archangel Gabriel (ff. 84v-96v); the Discourse of Jacob of Serug (the fourth-fifth century Syriac theologian) in praise of the Archangel Gabriel (ff. 97r-101r); further discourses of the Archangel Gabriel followed by a double page illustration of the Annunciation and birth of Christ (ff.101v-117v); the Discourse of John Chrysostom in praise the Archangel Raphael (ff. 118r-131r); and Miracles of the Archangel of Raphael (ff. 131v-138v).
52 paintings illustrate the volume which is bound in brown calf with blind stamped decoration over wooden boards with textile inlays on the inside covers. It was rebound and re-backed by the India Office in the late 19th century.
